questions.question: Only rocket engines can be propelled to space because
options: They can generate very high thrust
These engines can work on several fuels
questions.explanation: Rocket engines carry their own oxidizer and do not rely on atmospheric air for combustion, which is why they can operate in the vacuum of space. Jet engines are air-breathing and cannot function without an atmosphere.

questions.question: The universal gas constant of a gas is the product of molecular weight of the gas and
questions.explanation: The universal gas constant (R_u) is related to the specific gas constant (R) by the formula R_u = M × R, where M is the molecular weight of the gas.

questions.question: Vander Waal's equation of state of a gas is
questions.explanation: The Van der Waals equation is (p + a/v²)(v - b) = RT, where 'a' accounts for intermolecular forces and 'b' accounts for the volume occupied by the gas molecules.

questions.question: The radiative heat transfer rate per unit area (W/m²) between two plane parallel grey surfaces (emissivity = 0.9) maintained at 400 K and 300 K is (Stefan Boltzmann constant σ = 5.67 × 10⁻⁸ W/m² K⁴)
questions.explanation: The heat transfer rate per unit area is given by Q/A = σ(T₁⁴ - T₂⁴) / (1/ε₁ + 1/ε₂ - 1). With ε₁=ε₂=0.9, Q/A = [5.67×10⁻⁸(400⁴ - 300⁴)] / (2/0.9 - 1) ≈ 812 W/m².

questions.question: The efficiency η of any heat engine and efficiency ηR of a reversible heat engine operating between common heat source and heat sink are related as
questions.explanation: According to the Carnot's theorem, no heat engine operating between two given reservoirs can be more efficient than a reversible Carnot engine operating between the same two reservoirs. Therefore, the efficiency of any real engine (η) is always less than or equal to the efficiency of a reversible engine (ηR).
